metadata.title: Measurement of Physical Quantities
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: Mass, Weight, Scalars, Vectors, and the International System of Units.

preAssessment.question: A quantity expressed by magnitude alone is called:
The SI unit of mass is:

concepts.title: Mass and Weight
concepts.content: Mass is the amount of matter in a substance; it is a scalar quantity and remains constant everywhere. Weight is the gravitational force by which the earth attracts an object; it is a vector quantity and changes depending on location (e.g., poles vs. equator).

examples.text: Weight is minimum at the equator

keyPoints: Inertia is directly proportional to mass
Gravitational force acts on mass to create weight
concepts.funFact: The gravitational force on the moon is 1/6th of that on earth, so your weight on the moon would be significantly less, but your mass stays exactly the same!

concepts.title: Scalar and Vector Quantities
concepts.content: Scalar quantities only have magnitude (e.g., length, area, temperature). Vector quantities have both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, force). The International System of Units (SI) is based on seven fundamental quantities.
keyPoints: Accuracy in measurement is vital for science
concepts.funFact: In 1799, the first standard meter and kilogram were created in France, made of platinum, to ensure measurements were identical across the country!
